div.p:
1 25th Nov. 1940
Anon.
@@@@@@@@@@@@@@
For many centuries after (aft) Britain became an island
the says, the untamed forest was king.
On the matted boughs of that forest innumerable birds sang;
but their song was only heard by a few skin clad hunters
in the clearings. Did the desire to sing come to one
of those savages because he heard the birds sing? & didDid he
rest his stone axe against a tree for a moment? [illeg.] The tree
was felled; some sort of hut was (ws) made from its branches, and
then by degrees, the clearing became larger; the birds
fewer; and the human voice sung instead. & The first songs
are out of door songs; spring songs; summer songs; winter
songs. & for there was no comfort indoors (indoor), little
light and no books.

The eye therefore was xxxx more active in the first sxxxxxxx
singers than in ourselves. And some parts of England (Englab)
can still be seen as they saw it. Now and then by choosing
a view carefully to shut out a chimney or a bungalow (bungalwo),
we can still see a flat fen, reed whispering, waterlogged;
or a down, covered w still with turf only And overBut on the
down lies a green scar, along which the travellers came,
with the pack horses, dressed in wool, not in skins,
_____________________________________________________
by p. 3

2
the common voice, singing out of doors. He has no house.
He has a quick eye. connected, for the eye is a youthful
sense, with the body, with colour, with substance, rather
than with the mind. He lives a roaming (romaning) life, going from
house to house, stopping oftener at the back door than at
the front. He crosses the fields, mounts the hills, and
lies down on the grassy road (roa ) by the hawthorn to listen to
the nightingale.

By choosing a view (vuew) carefully to shut out a chimney or a
bungalow we can still see what saw-- the bird haunted
reed whispering fen; the down covered with turf, and the
scar long healed over the moor, over the down, along which
came when he made his journeys. He was
for the most part a simple singer, lifting a song or story
from other peoples lips, and letting the audience country people
join in the chorus. But now and again hxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx
he made a few lines himself that exactly corresponded to his emotion.
He was an artist.

body.div:
4 2
But for him of course we have to wait until winter was
past.

div.p:
3
died round about 1477. It was the printed book with
the authors name attached that killed him. [ After that the
audience was separate from the singer. ] And with himAnon died
that part of the song that the audience sang, the voice that
supplied the story, filled in the pauses, andadded sometimes
a nonsensical chorus. After that the song was attached to
the singerthe singer was separate from the audience:Anon is , or or Peter. He lived in
a house axmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxxx had features of his own,
has xmxmxmxxx features of his own and above all there is a past.
and behind him looks back at the past. Time has drawn its blue veil
over the horizon. Hexsxmxmxmxmxxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx He looks back to/over the forests & the roads.
One can [see?] is clearly when the present where there is a past behind it.
is dead; and the (th) have gone their
way. He-- as it happens to take the first of the individuals he is called (aclled) -- is the a parson
first in that long line of leisured and learned men who have
time to think about the past in the quiet of the (th)
parsonage. He is a representative (representa ive) man, often repeated with
little variation in other centuries (centruies). Like , like
Harrison the parson of had a library; and
dug up coins. Winter (Wint) is past and He alreadysees already sees the present
against a background.He is able to see Now that he has a past he can see the present The past has become so settled, so
ordered that the present looks ungainly and degenerate
xmxmxmxmxx against it. There is too much comfort; too many
pillows too many chimneys. The young (y ung) and
are not the men their fathers were. The smoke drawn up by
chimneys no longer salts and hardens (hard ns) them. They are tender
and subject to rheumatism. Also, they dress most
fantastically compared with their ancestors.
But the English (Eng ish) past as seen by only

served to show up the material change--the change that had
come (coke) over houses, furniture, clothing. There was no English
literature to show (s ow) up the change in the mind. There was were no
English (Ebglish) literature (literture) books to prove the decline of English literature
The English language (lnaguage) as tells us had gone
underground after the conquest for two centuries. Up stairs they talked French.
English language had gone downstairs (dow stairs) into the kitchen, into
the farmyard. Anon had sung his song at the back door in a
jargon that was as uncouth to Harrison as to ourselves.

Icham for woing al forwake
Wery no water in wore
An hendy hap ichabbe yghent
Ichot from hevene it is me sent

--- the words were as difficult for him to spell out as for
ourselves (ourslves). But they were more paiful, for they reminded him
of his lack of intellectual ancestry. His intellectual pedi
gree reaches back only to , , .
In order to have ancestors he must cross (ross) the ;
his ancestors (anc stors) by way of the mind are the Greeks and the
Romans. His page is burdened (burdneed), xxx with proofs [protestations?] of good breeding (breedg)
; ; ; ---
he quotes them to prove his good breeding (bredding) nobility of mind, as we, to prove
ours, quote (quite), or , or
The Greeks and the Romans occupied [ the same place] in his
mind the place that the Elizabethans (Elizabtehans) occupy in our own. The great (geeat) book
that were chained to the shelves of college libraries were
written in the learned tongues (tong es). Only the learned (leraned) and the
leisured noble read them. ...our ancient ladies of the court as
tells us, were to be found reading the [Greeks?] (G ) [and?]

5
LaTins as they sat at their needlework.

In the back ground then stood the marble busts of
Greeks (Greekd) and Romans, overpowering (overpwering), and and
. And in the foreground there is the house,
no longer a hut made with branches, no longer thick with
wood smoke. There is a pillow now, instead of the old log
with a dip for the head to rest in; glass fills the windows,
the ceilings are curiously worked; and the spoos and plates are of silver and pewter. Beyond (Beyo m) the
house (h use) there are a few roads wxmxmxmxmxmxx with great many roomed (roome)
Inns at intervals. The roads lead to ; a fine city;
and sometimes harrison The roads lead say here & there all across England
they lead to the channel ; Great travellers (tarvellers) there are who have
crossed (crosses) the and been to to . But
himself is no traveller (travller). Harrison has never been
more than forty miles from , he tells us. He tells us (s)
that he has a garden; that he digs for coins; and that he owns a mastiff.
The age of anonymity (anoynmity) is over when wxmxxxx the writer
tells us that.
"Winter is past".

then has emerged (em ged) from the forests and the floods.
He has a dog and a garden; He has books; and he digs in the
earth (aearth). e xhmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx. He has a name too,
but his name is of no great moment. It may be Harrison; it
may be ; [illeg.] or it may be Smith ( m th) or Jennings. There is very
little to him, save his name. He has no expression
on his face. He conveys to us chiefly the emptiness of England what he sees--England,
xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmxx; its emptiness;
its scarcity of (o) people; its few [roads?]; the predominance (predominence) of individuals.
The is the predominant figure. He counts her possessions (possession)
her ships; her palaces He watches her progresses from

6
along those few rutted and pitted roads to this great
house or that. She is parliament, press, society, law, order.
But the man who sees this is hard put to it write
describe what he sees. Writing is still an art that requires
great ceremony. It is a painful an elaborate (elborate) art.
What you make with the pen is separate from what you say
with the tongue (t nue). Words are stiff and cumbersome and resist
the efforts of the pen to shape them. Only a few years back
words were written beautifully in lustrous ink upon valuable
parchment, and the leaves bound together were chained to the
shelf and read in great discomfort on hard benches (ard nechces) in the cold (cod)
Even now when words are printed (pr nted) the great public (ublic) is not the
reader, or the paymaster. Written words must please a single
man (an) in the first place, & win his patronage., and the is
ceremoniously tended tendered to a in words as
ornate as the carvings and decorations that shocked him
in the fashionable Elizabethan (Elizavethan) house. For the book
must find its way into the hall, into the great room where the
nobles and the gentry have leisure to read it when they have
hunted (hjnuted) when they have ordered their estates after the business & pleasure of the day is over, when the
night has come and the ladies are busied with their embroidery (embroidey)
It is written for the great who wishlike to learn how their
ancestors (anecstors) lived; and who to read aloud the exploits of their
ancestors; or who wantwant a song to sing to their lutes and
citherns.

7
The great Elizabethan (Elizabetha) house is still in existence,
standing in its green island of park, separated often from
the high road only by a dip in the ground and a low red
wall. It is out of proportion now; either it is too
large, or the village with its eighteenth nineteenth twentieth (twentieh)
century shopps and villas is too small. With its conglomeration (congoler)
conglomeration (artion) of (o) roofs chapels chimneys (chimenys) it dwarfs its neighbours.
Inside all is kept as if , were
expected. The rxmxmxxx upright Elizabethan (Elizabthan) chairs stand round
the (th) walls. Their fringes (frimges) and their tapestry are not much
faded. The great oak tables are polished and heavy.
The carved chests and cupboards (cupbaords) look brand new.
The floor is strewn (ste wn) with rugs; the windows curtained
with red and green brocades; and cut glass chandeliers
hang down from the (th) xmxmxmxxx the decorated plaster work of the (th)
ceiling. Even the toys and knicknacks (t ys and kicknacks) have survived inate
intact; and there is the varnished pear shaped lute
upon which the Queen once played.

But where are the Elizabethans (Elizabthans) themselves? Human
life has receded from this convoluted iridescent shell.
upon which the sun of 1940 shines so brightly. The historians (histprians)
have ransacked their archives; their old chests; their
writing table drawers, their muniment rooms. They have
disinterred (disnterred) from the their faded pages fifteenth century the of and the of . They have [illeg.]
proved that they fought; and betrayed (baretred); and loved; for they
begot children (chi ldren). But it is a rudimentary life immured in
silence. The shell is polished; something moves and st
stirs inside the polished shell. But it the story of the

8
the Elizabethans. He turns (tunrs) away from the present. He does
not hear Anon singing at the back door; he ignores the
actors who were acting their crude dramas in the market
place. Upstairs he says in the great room
our ancient ladies of the (th) court are to be found reading
histories and chronicles (histoires and chornicles), the Greeks and the Latins (Geeks and the atins) as they
sat at their needlework (needlwork). not not And the scholars were reading (readong) the
classics (clasics) that were chained to the shelves in the college (th co ege)
libraries. Yet in spite of the printed book,
the common people were still at their (tgeir) lewd practices (pracises).

The preacher, going on his round on horseback, from
village to village found them at it and raised his voice
in anger. "riding on a journey homeward (homewar) from London" [London? Latimer?]
ixx about 1549 went to the Church to preach and found the
door locked fast against him. For more than half an hour he waited; and t at last
one of the parish came to me and said: Sir this is a
busy day with us, we cannot hear you, it is
day. The parish are gone abroad to gather for Robin Hood (Robin Hodd).
I was fain there to give place to Robin Hood. I thought my
[Pocket?] (Rocjet) would have been regarded, though I were not: but it
would not serve, it was fain to give place to Robin Hood's (Rbin hoods) men.
It is no laughing matter, my friends (freinds), it is a weeping matter,
a heavy matter, a heavy matter, under the pretence for
gathering for Robin Hood, a Traitor (Traoter), and a Thief (Theif), to put out
a preacher...."

Latimer made war against the minstrels and the
mummers. It was his voice that riddled the old superstitions (superstitons)
with scorn. For he was no antiquary. He did not dig in his

9
To was a txmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx nothing but a thief, to Latimer
the peasants doing him honour were still blind with
superstition (supersttion). He himself had walked "in the shadow (shdow)of death"
xmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmxxx till he was thirty.
Then gentle Mr master at had opened his
eyes. Now they saw through the old popish practices (pop sh paracices), the
old Pagan customs. He saw they saw England itself at this moment
in its reality. The cry of the women (wormen) is come up into my
eares he said. When he walked trying to read his book in
the garden there was (awas) a knocking (kocking)
at the gate. And his man (ma) came and said "Sir, there is one
that would speak with you (ou)." So he shut his book and went
out among the poor; into the prisons, into the fields.
The cry of the workmen "came up into my eares" he said He heard the poor Labourrers, gun makers,
Powdermen, Bow makers, arrowmakers, smiths, carpenters
soldiers and other crafts " crying that they (yhey) were unpaid.
They (The) found the poor without a goose or a pig for the
great were enclosing the fields. He went to the great man
and found him still in bed, after his hawking (hakwing) and
his hunting (hutning), and the hall full of poor suitors waiting to
make their plaints. [As for (fot) the Bishops, "they hawke, they
hunt (huntm) they carde, they dice, they pastime in their
prelacies with gallant gentlemen, with their dancing
minions and with their fresh companions..."]
He saw the curates in their velvet (velevet) shoes and slippers
"meet to dance the morris (themorris) dance". He saw the fine ladies
dressed in fa vardigalls with their hair puffed out (puffedout)
in tussocks (tuccosks) and French hoods. He saw the young (yo ng) men,

10
no longer shooting (shot ing) with the long bow, as his father had
taught him to shoot, but bowling, drinking, (drinkingl) whoring. And in (inh)
the streets of London he saw the harlot going to ec
execution, making merry as she went and crying, "that if
good (goof) fellows had kept touch with her, she had not been at
this time in that case." He noted the smell of
rotting bodies in (un) the churchyard at and
foretold plague to come. And in every village he found the
peasants going on pilgrimages, setting up candles, worshipping (worshippig)
pigs' (p gs) bones, and following (follwing) Robin Hood. How should they know
better (bet er) when there (the re) was no preaching in the pulpits, when
the words they heard were in a tongue they could not
understand?

So he went about England preaching in English,
no matter if he preached on horseback or stood under a tree.
It did not matter either if he spoke to the in person.
or preaching to the King in person. He did not moderate
his words. He spoke to the King himself in a voice that
stumbles, that repeats, that loses the thread of its argument
- one [illeg.] about them the first [sticky?] he [illeg.] -no matter, he will bring before the King the real state of
xxx England as (Englandas) it axmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxx He will unveil (unbeil)
show up, speak the truth, even if it brings him to the
faggot as it brought his master, the gentle Mr Bilney.
"who was for ever visiting prisoners (visitng risoners) and sick folk."
There is only ashort pace left him before he too will
stand outside the at and feel the flames
on his own flesh. So he pours out his anger;
So he lights up the state of England with his

11
He speaks in a voice that stumbles, that uses the plain
language of the farm from which he sprang, butIt is the
voice of of reason, of humanity (huamity), of common sense. [He will tell
the truth, even if it brings him as it brought the gentle
Master Bilney to the faggot.] He is aware that he has only
a short time in which to state his case--which is the case
of the poor, of the ]and there is there is an urgency in his preaching
wxxxxx so that it It is not a learned (learmed) voice; it is not
a courtly (c urtly) voice; it is the voice of a plain man, whose
bxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxxtearing down superstition,
a voice that does not issues from a
before he too goes to join Master Bilney at the faggot.
And yet for all his urgency, his severity, he is a man of
a people, a man of humour, offlesh and blood. He cracks his joke. He tells his story.
He has a [certain?] in [illeg.] for the human He is a man of the people, with a love of shooting (shotting), with a
respect for the gentry. But he sees, as the courtier (courteir) cannot
as the poor cannot, what superstition and ignorance (supersition and igno ance) are
rife in the land. It is for light and learning that he cries.
Give the money he implores that used to be
spent on " pilgrimage (pilgirmage) maters, in trentalls and masses in
purgatory matters" to poor mens sons so that they (thatthey) may become
scholars. It will come to (tp) pass there txmxmxmxmxx we shall have nothing
but a little English divinity , that will bring the realm
into a very barbarousness, and utter decay of learning."
xxxxx And while the peasants (th peasnts) are starving, and continuing
their gross superstitions (supe stitions), the he sees [illeg.] great (gr at) house is rising.
"All the affection of men now adays is in building gay"

12
and sumptuous houses, it is in setting up and pulling down,
and never have they done building."

p.s:
LetBut ironically enough, the preacher who was for
banishing and other such papish superstitions
was forging the very weapon (weapin) that gave the old minstrels (misntersl)
a new lease of life. When he spoke English (Eng ish) in the (hthe) pulpit,
when he said the Lords prayer (paryer) in English (Englisg), he was
putting English (Ebglish) into high places. He was rescuing it from
the jugglers and the bear leders at the back door. He was
giving the poets a language which was to bring all
the English crowding to the stage see the mummers (mu mers) acting on the (th) stage.

div.p:
Both Hxxxx xmxmxmxxmxxx and the preacher and the
chronicler, saw the great house (hous) rising on the ruins of
old. Bxmxmxmxmxmxx Each in his own way denounced (deno nced) the
gay sumptuous house, its [illeg.], its [illeg.]. It is there stilltoday, standing in
its green island of park, separated often from the high road
only by a dip in the ground and a low red wall. It dwarfs its
neighbours now It looks incongruous, standing among the
bungalows and the shops. With its conglomeration of chimneys
chapels roofs it looks out of proportion (porportion), stranded (starmded), derelict.
Inside all is kept as if Queen Elizabeth were still
expected. The upright ( p right) Elizabethan (Elizabthan) chairs stand round the
walls. Their fittings and tapestries (ftinges and tapestri s) are not much faded.
The great oak tables are heavy and polished. The carved
cupboards and chests look brand (ba nd) new. Cut glass chandeliers
hang down from the (th) decorated plaster work on the ceiling (th celing).
Even the knick knacks (k cki knacks) have survived (survibed)--; the inlaid work box,

13
The pear shaped lute on which the (th) herself once played.
Thir furniture remains; stiff, ornate, fantastic (fanatstic) and
uncushioned. There are the very "vardigalls" that roused the
preachers wrath. But the Elizabethans themselves (Elizabthans themslves) are silent.

We cannot hear them talking because thisit is to the
them in rhythm (rhym) of the Bible that they write their familiar prose. that they are unknown to us
There is therefore no little language; no warmth, no gaiety
nothing brief, intimate, colloquial (colloqauial) about them.
When writes to she is a preacher
addressing a subordinate. Fear of God and fear of man
surround her as with the (th) walls of a dungeon. She admonishes (admonhsies)
s she exhorts. The actual object--a basket of strawberries (strawberris)
is approached circuitously (ceremonieously). Greek and Latin
come as easily to her pen as a French phrase comes to ours.
SheThey wraps herself about in a cumbrous garment when she they tries
to talk (tal) Then (The ) again we cannot hear (haear) the rough English
voice that they heard at the back door. the voice (voi) of the
mummer and the minstrel. Nor can we see the paths that led
to the well and the tree. Robin Hood is gone
with all of his merry men (me y men). ThisThe gay and sumptuous house
that was O latimer full of oaths and coarseness and also of
learning , of courtesy (coutrsey), is an a lone isolated house;
a house full of furniture and finery but without inhabitants.
Bright contrasted colours meet on their faces; scarlet
and snow; ebony (enby) and gold; but there is no natural (natual) connection,
no common complexion.
The writer then must be a poet. --the writer (writ) who is

14
The writer, who is distinct from the minstrel, whose words
are printed with a book with his name to it, must be a poet.
For when familiar letters (lettres) are written in Biblical prose,
there is a limit to what can be put into words. There is a
barrier between the sayable and the unsayable. If he cannot
talk, he must sing. But though at the beginning of the
sixteenth (sixeneth) century the printing press has given the poet
a name, he is still unspecialised (unspeciliased). He is not wholly writer,
wholly musician or wholly painter. It seems possible that
the great English art may not be the art of words. He sees
acutely what is before him without the shadow or reflection; his ear is
stimulated by the sounds (ouns) of words spoken aloud. He must make
words sonorous (sornours), rhythm (rhytm) obvious. since they are to read
be out in company. "I spent most of my time" wrote Lady
"in playing at Glecko and hearing
read the ... Rivers used to read to me in
and Moll Neville in the
Further, words must move easily to the lilt of (o) the singing
voice, to the sound of lute and virginals. The English
sang their songs then, or played them . When London
was burning, noted that hardly one lighter or boat
in three that had the goods of a house in it, but there
was a pair of virginals in it." Music moved beneath the
words. No grammar bound them tightly together. They could
be read aloud; danced or sung to; but they could not

follow the pace of the speaking voice. They could not
enter (ent r) into the private world.

then--a little man with short hair,
a small band and cuffs" standing on the threshold of the
"gay and sumptuous house" at was separate from
from the minstrel; from the chronicler; and separate from
his audience. They no longer joined in the song and added
their own verses to the poem. But the book that had given
him a separate existence (existnce) had brought into being a little
group of readers. Thaxmxmmxxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxxsx
xmxmxmxmxxx It had to find its way into the great room where
the gentry sat at leisure when they had hunted and hawked
and done the business of their estates. That audience (audeince) at
once began to exert its pressure. What is the book that will
please my patron ? What is the theme that
will recommend itself to ? Whom must I praise, whom
may I satirise? At once come into existence some of
those innumerable influences that ( at) are to tug, to distort,
to thwart; as also they are to stimulate (srimulate) and draw out.
The poet is no longer (long r) a nameless wandering voice, but
attached to his audience. tethered (tehetred) to one spot and played
upon by (my) outside influences. Some are visible to himself
only; others show themselves only when time has past.
As the book goes out into a larger (larher), a more varied audience
these influences become more and more complex. According to
its wealth (welaht), its poverty, its education, its ignorance,
the public demands what satisfies its own need--poetry,
history, instruction, a story to make (makr) them forget the

16
their own drab lives. The thing (t ing) that the writer has to say
becomes increasingly cumbered. It is only to be discovered
in a flash of recognition-- Thus some say that their beards
bristle when they hxmxmxxx come (coke) upon it; others that a
thrill runs down the nerves of the thigh. To disengage the
song from the effect of the audience becomes as time goes on
a task for the critic-- that specially equipped taster
who was not yet in existence when the emerged
from the depths deeps of anonymity.

Those depths, xxxxx those long years of
anonymous minstrelsy, folk song (fo song), legend and words that had
no name attached to them, lay behind him. Their confusion pressed upon him. He was conscious
of them. "For why a Gods name " he exclaimed "
may not we, as else the Greeks, have the kingdom of our
own language...." ? He was word conscious; an artist;
aware of his medium; that words are not paint, nor music;
but have their possibilities; their limitations. To be thus
aware the writer (writ) must have a past behind him. To Spenser the
golden age was . "Dan Chaucer, well of English
undefiled..." He trusted that the infusion sweet
Of thine own xxxxxx spirit which doth in me survive"
might help him. He looks back to Chaucer (Cahucer); he descends (descneds) from
Chaucer. It was Chaucer who gave him the standard (standdard) by which
to measure his own works (wor s). But where the modern writer
attacks the actual (actul) work of some of the generation that
has just gone, making that book the starting point
in another direction, Spensers revolt was against no
particular (particular) writer-- who was there writing English except

17
Chaucer (Cahicer)?-- but against (agianst) the language itself, its decay,
since Chaucer, its corruption. Perhaps Chaucers crudity
served as an antidote to his own facility. Perhaps too
he used the crabbed (th carbbed) old words, not as we now might revert to
them to bring back[illeg.] sharpness where when much use has worn
words smooth; but to restrain what was to come. He was, as
we cannot be, aware of the future. Everywhere, (E rywhere,) in ballads (ballds),
in talk at the tavern, at the back door, he must have heard
something rising, bursting up, from beneath (benaeth). Was ( as) it partly
to restrain the coming insurrection that he looked back to
the ?

As so often happens it was the attraction of what is opposed that drew to .
For them, thatthere was no other connection between the
Queen and the . but no [illeg.]xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxm
xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxx The one is clear (claer) sharp definite;
the other sensuous, sinuous dallying (daalying). The one is direct,
about this real man, this real woman, here and now.
the other wanders through time which is neither past nor
present; through lands (throu nlands) that are neither known nor unknown (unknwon).
Unlike he has ceased (c ased) to believe in giants (ginats).
The faith that the nobles had in 1470 of the real existence of has turned (tunred) to
scepticism. His poem lacks the some reality of the
that Malory achieved [illeg.]. Malory too was behind (ehind) him. [But the faith
that the old nobles had in the reality of has
turned to scepticism.] Where Malory sees directly Spenser sees
at a distance. He sees Knights and ladies with regret, with
desire (dseire), but not with belief. There is no (nos) sharpness in
his figures; no edge; no anguish (angusih); no sin; no On the other
hand he shows us as Malory (alory) cannot the world surrounding them.
He realises (realis s) time and change. And looking back, from a

18

Spenser standing on the (standinn othe) threshold of the great house

For He cannot confine emotions within one body [himself?]. He must

wandering voice, but the (th) voice of a man practising an art,
asking for recognition, and bitterly conscious of his
separation relation from the world, of the worlds scorn.

At last one man speaks (s aks) in his own person. The wandering voices (voice)

The play was anonymous. That fact is by itself
enough to show largely how the play was a common product,
written by one hand, but so moulded in transition (tranition) from the
written to the spoken that the author had no sense of
property in it. It was half the work of the audience. But
yet the audience is dumb (sdumb). That silence is one of the (th) deep
gulfs that lies between us and the Elizabethan (Elizabetahn) play.
Fifteen hundred people, Dr Greg (Greg) says, hexmxxx
went to the play, for the most part, presumably,
in the penny part of the house, And these The presence
of (o) these apprentices, soldiers and citizens is obvious.
It draws up the extravagance the hyperbole as a sheet of
paper draws up a fire. It causes that glow that speed that
audacity which make the writer capable of great strides and
vast audacities beyond his private reach. Yet the
audience says nothing . It makes no comment. It sits silent.
To understand that silence we (w) must compare it

with our (theour) own attitude say at the ballet
or at the in their early days. A new art comes upon us
so suddenly, so surprisingly (surprisningly) that we are silent,
recognising something true, which we recognise but cannot measure.
To the Elizabethans, after the long silence of England,
the hidden power of words to say what was in them must have been
overwhelming. After ages of of scattered hints, a few
wild songs, here and there a chronicle (chornicle) or a history (hitsiry), they
suddenly came to [illeg.] out into the open and saw human life as it is
at this moment. They saw themselves. It is a curious inversion
We see realise the blood flesh and blood of the Elizabethans
because we see it in the reflected (r fl cted) in the drama.
We neither see nor hear them in person; we see (s ee) and hear
them in the reflection. But if the audience sat silent
as they saw themselves (themslves) there on the stage between the
stews, they but they saw themselves with rapture. Again and again
the protested against the intoxication
that was brewed (b rewed) in the Playhouse. The attraction was
irresistible. There at the Rose, at the at the
men and women who had never seen (neverseen) themselves (themslves) yet, whose only
reading (readung) was history (histoy) or sermons, or some old chronicle (chonicle) of
Knights and ladies, , and perhaps could not even read,
but spent all their days struggling, loving, cheating (chaeting),
burrowing in the little festering streets round (rounf) ,
saw their very own lives composed, adored (adoredn), and heard at
last (kast) their (thier) dreams their aspirations (aspriarions) their satires their
profanities spoken out loud in poetry.

The play then owes its extravagance, and its riot,
and its plot and its glow to the audience (audie ce) in the penny seats.
